ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Soret effect and multicomponent transport
ygData.msgSnippet: I looked into this, and much to my surprise it seems you can t turn on thermal diffusion in flame simulations from Python or MATLAB. It works from C++.  In an

I looked into this, and much to my surprise it seems you can't turn  
on thermal diffusion in flame simulations from Python or MATLAB. It  
works from C++.  In an older version of the Cantera Python interface,  
this capability existed, but somehow it was left out when part of  
this interface was rewritten.  I have now put it in.

 From Python, you can call a method 'enableSoret()' that turns on  
thermal diffusion. This change has been checked into the CVS  
repository. See example flame2.py where this is used.



On Apr 22, 2007, at 10:38 AM, rustoleump wrote:

> Does anyone know if the diffusion effects (Soret, Dufour, etc) are  
> enabled automatically
> with the multicomponent transport?  I'm using the freely  
> propagating adiabatic flame
> example with an H2-O2 mechanism and I'm not able to match the flame  
> speed with the
> literature.  My results are about 7% too high.  When I checked the  
> source code, I found the
> line m_do_soret(false) in the file StFlow.cpp and it seems to me  
> that this would force the
> Soret effect to be off.  I've run the same grid with multicomponent  
> and mixture averaged
> transport with different results - the mixture averaged is slightly  
> higher as I would expect.
> I have changed the line to m_do_soret(true), recompiled and it  
> didn't change the result.  I
> appreciate any help.
>
> Thanks.
> Rusty
>
